title: Analysis & Results
text: We computed summary statistics of adolescent fertility and created a histogram and boxplots by income group to understand the overall distribution and how it varies across income levels.

title: Analysis & Results
text: We computed summary statistics of adolescent fertility and created a histogram and boxplots by income group to understand the overall distribution and how it varies across income levels.

title: Analysis & Results
text:
Time Trends
We plotted the mean adolescent fertility over time by income group and four selected countries (Brazil, Ethiopia, India, and Japan). These plots show that adolescent fertility has declined globally but remains much higher in low-income and some lower-middle-income countries.

title: Analysis & Results
text:
Maps
We created two world maps (1960 and 2023) that color countries by their adolescent fertility rates. Comparing these maps illustrates substantial global progress and persistent geographic disparities.

title: Analysis & Results
text:
Regression
We fit simple regression models with adolescent fertility as the response and year and income group as predictors to quantify the overall downward time trend and the differences across income groups.

title: Adolescent Fertility – Project Overview
text:
This website summarizes our MA705 Project 1 on global adolescent fertility (births per 1,000 women ages 15–19) using World Bank data from 1960 to 2023.

Data source: World Bank World Development Indicators, indicator SP.ADO.TFRT.
Main question: How have adolescent fertility rates changed over time across the world, and how do patterns differ by region and income group?
Key contributions:

Cleaned and tidied adolescent fertility data into a panel dataset.
Enriched the data with World Bank region and income group.
Created visualizations to compare distributions, trends over time, and geographic patterns.
Fit simple regression models to quantify time trends and differences across groups.

title: Adolescent Fertility – Project Overview
text:
This website summarizes our MA705 Project 1 on global adolescent fertility (births per 1,000 women ages 15–19) using World Bank data from 1960 to 2023.

Data source: World Bank World Development Indicators, indicator SP.ADO.TFRT.
Main question: How have adolescent fertility rates changed over time across the world, and how do patterns differ by region and income group?
Key contributions:

Cleaned and tidied adolescent fertility data into a panel dataset.
Enriched the data with World Bank region and income group.
Created visualizations to compare distributions, trends over time, and geographic patterns.
Fit simple regression models to quantify time trends and differences across groups.

title: Data & Methods
text:
We use adolescent fertility data from the World Bank World Development Indicators (indicator code SP.ADO.TFRT). The raw files include:

API_SP.ADO.TFRT_DS2_en_csv_v2_14702.csv (main time series for adolescent fertility).
Metadata_Country_API_SP.ADO.TFRT_DS2_en_csv_v2_14702.csv (country metadata such as region and income group).

title: Data & Methods
text:
We use adolescent fertility data from the World Bank World Development Indicators (indicator code SP.ADO.TFRT). The raw files include:

API_SP.ADO.TFRT_DS2_en_csv_v2_14702.csv (main time series for adolescent fertility).
Metadata_Country_API_SP.ADO.TFRT_DS2_en_csv_v2_14702.csv (country metadata such as region and income group).

title: Data & Methods
text:
Retrieval and Cleaning
We manually downloaded the CSV files from the World Bank Open Data website and saved them in the Project 1/Adolescent fertility rate folder of our MA705 project. In our Python notebook, we then:

Loaded the raw CSVs into pandas DataFrames.
Skipped the descriptive header lines and dropped empty columns.
Converted the data from wide format (one column per year) to long tidy format (one row per country–year).
Merged the fertility data with country metadata using the Country Code variable.
Renamed columns, converted data types, and removed rows with missing adolescent fertility.

title: Data & Methods
text:
Enrichment and Quality Checks
We enriched the dataset with region and income group, and used groupby and aggregation to compute averages by year, region, and income group. We also added simple data-quality checks (for example, assert statements to verify there are no missing values in key variables and that the number of rows and value ranges are reasonable).
